text:
How can i achieve filters like these..
<https://preview.hs-sites.com/_hcms/preview/template/multi?is_buffered_template_layout=true&portalId=4724491&tc_deviceCategory=undefined&template_layout_id=26115502902&updated=1582708999771>
Nope... I tried to format a date in email and it wouldn't work. There's more restrictions with HUBL in email, unfortunately.
if you are using HubSpot blogs, you could use tags.  add the tags as data-filters on the posts.  whip up some js to filter on them.  there are libraries to help if you need them
What the is correct syntax to format numbers when pullingfrom a hubdb table? Like make 40300 > 40,300. I think I have to use  |format but not sure what’s the correct syntax
I know you can do this with `|regex_replace`, but I am interested in this since that won’t work with a multi-language setup.
Maybe you could combine the `|format_currency` filter and use the `|regex_replace` to strip out any currency… IDK that’s a bit hacky. I feel like this should be a native HubL filter
Hey John thanks for the idea. It didn’t work for me with |regex_replace but it worked with |cut()  very weird that there’s not native solution :/ thank you for the idea thoZ

hello! Does anyone know if there is a way to query whether a variable contains a string?

I’m aiming to use a menu to store contact info and social links. I’d like to be able to do something like this

```if child.label contains "Phone"```
Then if it contains that string, I’d toggle the visibility of a phone icon. Same with “facebook” for the FB icon etc. The reason I don’t want to use a simple equals statement is that the phone number may change. For example they might set the menu label to `Phone: 1300 999 999` but change the figure in the future.

Is this possible?
